title: How to Keep Your Photographs from Being Snapshots

steps.headline: Have a message.
steps.description: Say something with your photograph. Even if you are just sharing the beauty of what you see

steps.headline: Be sure that your photograph has a main subject.
steps.description: If your viewer has to figure out what you are portraying, then it doesn't have a subject.

steps.headline: Be sure that your subject has a center of interest.
steps.description: This works with the main subject.

steps.headline: Be ready to change the orientation of your photograph.
steps.description: The default of a camera is landscape. That would be horizontal...basically 4 X 6. Portrait is a vertical type shot with 'dimensions' of 6 X 4.

steps.headline: Move around.
steps.description: If you take the photo now and it is a simple snapshot. Change your perspective and it becomes a memorable photograph.

steps.headline: If your subject is moving, consider where it will be when you take the photo.
Look at the background.
steps.description: Will it detract, or enhance, your image. Is there a way that you can 'fix' it.

steps.headline: If you can, move your subject around.
steps.description: Obviously, you can't move the forest (or the tree), but when you can, move things around.

steps.headline: Think about what your viewer will be looking at when they see the photograph.
steps.description: Do your best to direct their eye.

text: Have a message. Say something with your photograph. Even if you are just sharing the beauty of what you see Be sure that your photograph has a main subject. If your viewer has to figure out what you are portraying, then it doesn't have a subject. Be sure that your subject has a center of interest. This works with the main subject. Be ready to change the orientation of your photograph. The default of a camera is landscape. That would be horizontal...basically 4 X 6. Portrait is a vertical type shot with 'dimensions' of 6 X 4. Move around. If you take the photo now and it is a simple snapshot. Change your perspective and it becomes a memorable photograph. If your subject is moving, consider where it will be when you take the photo.  Look at the background. Will it detract, or enhance, your image. Is there a way that you can 'fix' it. If you can, move your subject around. Obviously, you can't move the forest (or the tree), but when you can, move things around. Think about what your viewer will be looking at when they see the photograph. Do your best to direct their eye.
